$1 BILLION #Bitcoin IS NOT BULLISH.

Let's say you are 20 (or you have a 20 year old kid).

You've got 45 years until you're 65.

Let's say #Bitcoin has a 24% CAGR for 45 years... Forget that #BTC's historical CAGR is ridiculously higher, that 99% of capital is ahead of us, market multiplier only goes up from here, and that fiat debasement only accelerates.

That is $1,119,628,313 per #BTC upon age 65.

You've still got 20+ years to live... Remember that by 2069 life expectancy will hopefully be significantly longer!

If we assume a CAGR of 30% and you live to 100 that is $1,869,818,789,476,726 per #Bitcoin.

Is a $1.8 quadrillion #BTC sustainable in real terms?🤣

Ok, how about nominal terms?🤔

How do we price future tech in terms of current tech?🤯

"You're crazy"... Ok... My grandmother is 92 years old and the S&P 500 was literally $4 when she was born. 👀

The stock market did a 1,200x in 92 years despite:
slower tech innovation,
non-finite market cap,
lower systemic USD inflation,
only exposure to a portion of the USA,
only 1/20th of the humans having property rights,
& starting out with a major share of global wealth.

Even if you think I'm insane it is a FACT if the S&P 500 simply kept pace with the last 100 years it would be $75 million in the next century... From increased tech and inflation alone the S&P 500 is going to hundreds of millions of USD political currency units (even though #Bitcoin demonetizes it).

Who knows how this plays out but you'll may live to see #Bitcoin at almost every fiat price point you can imagine... Even if the USD doesn't hyperinflate.

Forget $1.8 quadrillion #Bitcoin.
Forget $1 billion #Bitcoin.
Forget $100 million #Bitcoin.

If #Bitcoin went to $2 million in the next few years are you **seriously** prepared?...

1) Do you have multiple self-custody setups?

2) Have you reduced single points of failure (including you?)

3) Do you EVEN HAVE self custody?

4) Are you protected against theft, lost keys, or passing?

5) Do you have jurisdictional arbitrage? Keys in multiple countries?

6) Will your spouse, partner, or kids have the ability and education to manage $10's of millions worth of #Bitcoin alone in a few years if they needed to?

7) Do you have #Bitcoin in your IRA, SMSF, pension, or trust yet?

8) Do you still have single-sig wallets/devices in your house or "safety" deposit box?

9) Do you realize that all of these things are easily possible for you? It doesn't matter if you only have "a little" #BTC you still have signifigant wealth.

10) Do you have ANY exposure to the lowest risk institutional-grade multi-sig collaborative custody?... How do you expect to get the best terms or most favorable treatment otherwise if you don't?

Have you yet asked yourself what will happen when millions of people ask themselves these ten questions at once?... Do you seriously want to procrastinate this?

Maybe we've got 3-5 years before these questions matter... However there are 10 million+ people who will have the need for this and I can assure you @TheBTCAdviser will be front and center - given a perfect track record since 2016. Nobody comes close to what @TheBTCAdviser has created and it's why I've got my stack in that precise setup.

The reason I talk #Bitcoin, self custody, and @TheBTCAdviser is not because I need to or a lack of demand... it is because I understand we have a massive supply-demand squeeze coming and I'm trying to warn you.

You (and millions of others) don't need a $1 billion or even a $1 million #BTC to start feeling significant pressures on peace of mind.

You (and millions of others) don't need 100% exposure to collaborative custody multi-sig to reap of benefits. Most won't want to be all-in one model which (in irony) makes the market only bigger and the importance to gain exposure only higher.

Even if #Bitcoin only goes to $800,000 and you only had 25% in a collaborative custody arrangement the peace of mind, helping hand, and lack of single point of failure is going to be so important.

You've got your hands on #Bitcoin RIGHT NOW and don't realize it's like buying the S&P 500 at $4 in 1932... and we are about to accelerate into 2132 TECH and PRICES in the next few decades.

Ignore me about #Bitcoin, fine. I don't care. Just get off zero.🫡

Ignore me about self custody, fine. In a long enough time horizon all counter-party risk rises to 100% failure rate and you'll learn then.🙄

Ignore me about collaborative custody, fine. We've got plenty of demand. In 5 years people will ask why I didn't warn them to at least consider it.🤷‍♂️

Don't worry, other competitors will arise besides @TheBTCAdviser with legit services for collaborative custody multi-sig... The only difference is they were not helping clients since 2016 and they won't achieve zero single point of failure.

Call a $10,000,000 #Bitcoin "moon-math" all you want but I'm trying to warn you max pain is not down... it is up.

Why?

If I had an infinite money printer why would I force #BTC price down when I could just force price up faster than the security of HODL'ers self custody? Don't scare them out of selling their coins in fear of crash - scare them into selling their coins in the face of green omega candles they weren't prepared for.

We have less in common with the future than the past... The fear of NGU will someday eclipse the fear of NGD.

Even if the USD does not hyperinflate and we don't see hyperbitcoinization this is still true - that's how bullish #Bitcoin is.

$1 million #Bitcoin is nothing and yet most people are NOT prepared for it - even those that own #Bitcoin...

Prepare for a 100x now, because you (or your kids) may live to see a $1 billion #Bitcoin... Even without hyperinflation.

People today laugh at me because I'm bullish.

In truth, people will laugh at me in the future with how bearish I am because I'm trying to explain 2132 in terms of 1932 prices and tech.

A few sats in 2124 purchase WAY MORE than 1 billion sats in 2024... Act like it.

Nobody is bullish enough and most of you aren't taking your #Bitcoin security seriously enough.🤷‍♂️🧡

Get off zero.
Get more bullish.
Get self custody solid.

The Pyth week in review 🔮

Five new integrations, Pyth Data on @MerlinLayer2, and Ambient joining as a new Pyth Data Provider were some of the highlights of the week.

Learn more below:

⛓️ New Blockchains

- @MerlinLayer2 — a Bitcoin Layer 2 that integrates ZK-Rollup network, decentralized oracle network, and on-chain BTC fraud proof modules.

🏦 New Data Providers

@ambient_finance — a decentralized exchange (DEX) protocol that allows for two-sided AMM combining concentrated and ambient constant-product liquidity on any arbitrary pair of blockchain assets.

🤝 dApps Integrations

- @doubler_pro — an open financial strategy protocol platform aiming to to optimize cryptocurrency asset investment strategies.
- @BloomOnBlast — a leverage DEX for rebasing assets, utilizing @Blast_L2's yield mechanisms.
- @EasyXdefi — a decentralized perpetual protocol where users can get exposure to many crypto assets on @Blast_L2.
- @vegaprotocol — create and trade derivatives products like dated futures or perpetual markets on a fully decentralized network.
- @bitsmiley_labs — a Bitcoin-native stablecoin protocol built on @MerlinLayer2.

💱 New Price Feeds

- $SWETH — an ERC-20 token, by @swellnetworkio, that represents a user’s staked ETH inclusive of accrued rewards and penalties from the consensus layer, and MEV and ‘tips’ from the execution layer.
- $PXETH — one of the Ethereum liquid staking token of @redactedcartel and used by Dinero, a high-yielding liquid staking solution.
- $METH — Mantle Staked Ether serves as the value-accumulating receipt token from the Mantle Liquid Staking Protocol
- $EZETH — the liquid restaking token representing a user’s restaked position at @RenzoProtocol.

I like these @sagamonkes, but even moreso I like what they represent.

I've never been a chain maxi (cuz it's stupid) but before a cpl months ago I had only ever bought nfts on eth.

But when I heard @killabearsnft was teasing an expansion to Solana, I decided to bridge some ETH over and check it out.

What I didn't know at the time was... a simple journey into jpegs, quickly turned into a dive deep down the rabbit hole 🐇

Into the incredible story of a resilient, die-hard, passionate community.

A community who got giga-rugged by a raging sociopath, while much of the broader crypto community shit on them, clowned them, wrote them off, and left them for dead.

And not only did this community survive, they shipped. 

All throughout the bear. Setting themselves up to be positioned as perfectly as possible when the inevitable turn in the market happened.

And now, here we are.

To those who believed, this is no surprise. @blknoiz06 was pounding it into everyones' heads day after day (wish I listened earlier, ser!)

And because of their work, grit, and resilience... this time around when the real normie money comes back in, 

I believe SOL will be their gateway.

Bonk and WIF will onboard them, just like Doge and Shib in cycles past.

They will see good UI/UX, fast and cheap transactions, and  a plethora of ponzinomic pleasures to suit any risk appetite.

And they will come in through the phones which were never supposed to succeed, yet just sold more preorders in 1 day than v1's entire year of sales...

Which brings us back to @sagamonkes - dropped for free to Saga holders at a very pivotal time in Solana's short, but storied history.

A few simply placed pixels, which represent the triumphant journey of the underdog who was left for dead, and came back to life even stronger.

Even the great @aeyakovenko rocks one as his pfp.

Huge shoutout to all the manlets. Have met some great and incredibly smart people since I came into the ecosystem. 

Especially enjoying @0xMert_'s hilarious responses to the sol haters too. (and shout to @Lightspeedpodhq for putting out some incredible content)

It's clear what's happening here on SOL is something great, and I'm excited to dive deeper into the eco, and for the rest of the Killabears community to experience it.

Because we too know what it's like to be underestimated, and overcome adversity too. So I think we'll fit right in over there.

Solana devs

if you are getting:

TransactionExpiredBlockheightExceededError

what's happening is your transaction keeps getting forwarded to the next block leader (but not getting included) until the blockhash expires

important: this is not an RPC issue (unless their global coverage is awful and distance to the leader is always far)

patch:

- note it's *impossible* to fully 100% fix this until the solana mainnet scheduler is fully deterministic (release 1.18)
- add fees
- minimize distance to block leader and minimize distance to your RPC nodes from your servers/clients (it's kind of a race)
- add better retries
- consider using durable nonces if you don't need instant finality

🦄💎

this is what the top 10 of coinmarketcap looked like when i joined crypto in 2016

things were so simple back then. there was a total of 1-3 new coins per months and you had weeks to prepare for the icos and most people read most whitepapers back then.

ethereum had a smaller mc than @blur_io back then. it was 626 million.

reddit was as big as twitter.

hardly any scammers ever.

we were wo hopeful.

today, a solana memecoin shoots past a billion usd at a moment’s notice

one last bull

🧵 Solana 0-1 for Beginners

Solana is 3800x faster than Ethereum, 10,000x faster than Bitcoin

w/ fees @ pennie's or lower

Step 1: download a Solana wallet, the most used are Phantom(https://t.co/uAxgGHvBuz) or Solflare(https://t.co/OsAHOK2MJ9)

Step 2: fund your wallet, you can do this from a CEX such as Coinbase or Binance, or through a bridge like Allbridge(https://t.co/HAebQ6lkX2) if you have funds on a different blockchain

Step 3: decide what you want to do onchain, Solana is ripe with active development in many areas, here are a few:

-staking/validating (@jito_sol, @MarinadeFinance, @marginfi)
-nfts (@MagicEden)
-trading(@JupiterExchange)

Step 4: find your community, there are plenty of people exploring and building on Solana, either on X or Telegram. 

be weary of people who are getting paid for promo or using their followers for exit liquidity. if someone is shilling a new ticker every hour and the chart(https://t.co/gCzX8AoDAZ) goes down immediately after, stay away. 

Always make sure you are checking URLs and transactions before you interact to avoid any malicious activity.

if you found this helpful, welcome and enjoy the most accessible and user friendly chain in crypto🫡

Its an inscription on ethereum blockchain. Its fully on chain and immutable. The current system for doing a token allows us to mint the tokens in batches. In this case its a total supply of 4.20 million tokens in batches of 4200. So each mint is 4200 tokens and you only pay gas.  Gas is cheaper this way as well. Once they mint out we can move to a more familiar method of swaps with @oxfacet which is like uniswap for ethscriptions and that will parcel out those batches to where you sell 1-however many you want. Congratulations @primex_official for going live on #Ethereum! 

It’s a huge milestone & we can’t wait to see what comes next.

Many altcoins are in a corrective state. However, which will recover the hardest?

Let's dive in. 

2024 is a continuation of 2023. Bitcoin will cont to steal most of the spotlight until after the havening (IMO, BTC ETF probably tomorrow). 

Afterward (mid 2024), Ethereum will take the stage in a big way.

I base this on the fact that many Eth L2s are close to completing legendary technical scaling and interoperable achievements. 

Additionally, Ethereum is the most likely to receive institutional interest after Bitcoin for following ETF approval. 

I'm unbothered by unaligned L1s that have shot their shot early. The bull run has just started, and the most important parts have yet to come (they know it'll be hard to compete once Ethereum DeFi summer returns).

So, who will rally the hardest shortly and during the heat of 2024? 

IMO, those most closely aligned and solving problems for Ethereum (especially those designed to grow with Ethereum or Polygon). 

L2s (#Polygon), DeFi (QuickSwap DragonFi 2.0), DePIN, interoperability, data availability, gaming, & oracles will all easily receive much interest. 

The recovery will come to those with the most potent narrative, but actual adoption and shipping will matter much more than past bull runs. 

Things are getting serious due to the institutional aspect and coming regulation. 

You guys know which projects I'm most bullish on. Let's goooooo! 🟪🟪🟪

🌐 We're excited to unveil a dedicated hub for developers and innovators to explore, create, and revolutionize the Ethereum ecosystem using EthereansOS!

🌟 What is Builders Academy?
Builders Academy brings both seasoned developers and new innovators together to build using the EthereansOS Stack. This is a dedicated space to brainstorm new use cases, deploy organizations, tokens and items, and build new protocols using the EthereansOS contracts.

💡 Open to All!
Whether you're a seasoned builder or developer, or a curious newcomer with no coding experience and only an idea, our doors are open. Get hands-on with our tools and bring your unique ideas to life.

🛠️ Why Builders Academy?
We believe in empowering builders and innovators to unlock Ethereum's full potential. That's why we've launched the Builders Academy – a dedicated space where developers and innovators can come together to explore, create, and be rewarded for using EthereansOS tools.

🏆 Rewards for Innovation

capacity of Ethereum (~600b gas/ day vs ~110b gas/day).
Finally, a reminder - the gas limit is voted on by validators. They can vote it up or down each block. I am advocating for a modest increase of 50% - from 30m to 45m.

If you agree, start voting 45m! (6/6)

...can already cost hundreds of dollars we should not pretend Ethereum is not already in a place where you can only use it with significant capital. Yeah, sure, you might just want to "read" state but who would really do that if they can never transact on the chain. (4/6)

How can this increase by 10x over the next years? To me the answer can not be that transaction costs increase by 10x - at least part of it needs to be Ethereum simply offering more block space.
Yes, increasing the block limit will put more load on full nodes. But we should (2/6)

Call me crazy, but I think a chain's value should come from the utility it provides. Ethereum is fundamentally offering block space. Currently users are paying ~$2.5b per year for this block space and ultimately this is a measurement of the utility Ethereum provides. (1/6)

Something big is brewing in the Solana ecosystem: Crypto Undeads. This 10,000-strong collection isn't just another drop; it's a convergence of narratives, communities, and a bold mission👇

Solana 🤝 Ethereum

Their aim to bridge Solana and Ethereum is monumental. With communities converging across chains, this project stands as a unifying force in the space.

Unique Art

They've adopted a cool pixel art style that blends punk vibes with awesome digital portraits, making them stand out with clean aesthetics. It's a nod to inclusivity.

Defying the Narrative

In the face of "NFTs are dead" headlines, Crypto Undeads emerges as a rebuttal, branding themselves "crypto undeads" – kind of catchy, right? 
It's a testament to blockchain resilience, a narrative that resonates across the entire space.

Clear Vision

@knownasdollar , one of the most respected and well-connected individuals in the Punks community, set out with a vision—to forge one of Solana's most robust IPs. He wants the project to be the long-term hold for collectors on Solana, just like punks are on Ethereum.

Big Hype & Cool Collabs

The collaborations are staggering. Partnerships with @CyberKongz, @KaijuKingz, @Claynosaurz, @PirateNation, @assetdash, and @ChimpersNFT signal an embrace of diverse communities, stirring up unparalleled excitement.

Fair & Open for Everyone

They're meticulously handpicking allocations to prevent bots from taking over, ensuring equal shares for Solana and Ethereum communities and making sure everyone gets a fair chance.

Finally, with the market looking good and Bitcoin receiving a thumbs-up soon, the timing couldn't be better.

I believe "Golden Ratio" is going to be the staple for gen art on Ordinals, as much as "Squiggles" and "Autoglyphs" were for Ethereum

On the surface, it's beautiful art, but on a deeper level it represents an important transition that is about to happen in Ordinals.

Why do I think that? It's both a recursive and cursed collection.

Recursive inscriptions were an incredibly innovative feature added to the Ordinals protocol, allowing you to reference data from other ordinals last year.

I expect recursiveness to grow in popularity, as it is a much cheaper inscription option and enables a new level of composability between ordinals that wasn't previously possible. I predict we will see an explosion in recursive PFP collections, as much as we will see an explosion in recursive gen art collection.

Why do I think this particular collection warrants to be the "grail" of recursive collections? Just look at it. The art itself is recursive, and what better to express this recursiveness by using the most popular proportion in nature - the golden ratio.

What is @BitcoinCats1Cat?🐱

❤️Giveaway at the End❤️

Bitcoin Cats is the GameFi platform for the Bitcoin Ecosystem. Through mapping the Bitcoin Assets (BRC20, Ordinals NFT and others) to Ethereum (and other Layer2) networks, BitcoinCats brings many new elements to the Bitcoin Assets, including but not limited to Play2Earn, Staking, Farmland, SocialFi and many others. The mission of BitcoinCats is to build the next-gen gaming ecosystem across Bitcoin and EVM networks, with the communities of both sides, together!

Genesis #BitcoinCats #NFTs will soon launch on @bakery_swap!

Bullish Points
✅ Token
✅ Game
✅ NFT

Token
$1cat is the native token of Bitcoin Cats Gaming Ecosystem. It is originally inscribed on Bitcoin and part of it is bridged / wrapped to Ethereum to benefit from the well developed DeFi and GameFi infrastructure.

$1CAT is the Utility token with the BitcoinCats gaming ecosystem, which can be used to buy & upgrade in-game assets including the avatars, pets, equipments, farmlands and so forth. It also serves like tickets, enabling players to access special features. Finally, it is also a memecoin, with a super cute cat as its logo.

Game
Bitcoin Cats is a versatile gaming platform that offers more than just pixel games; it features AAA-level 3D MMORPGs, bringing a new dimension to gaming. The platform encompasses a range of Web3 functionalities including mining, NFT trading, and DAOs, as well as traditional Web2 elements like PvP, PvE, and guild formation. The gameplay is dynamic, with continuous updates to keep the experience fresh and engaging.

NFT
BitcoinCats NFT is the collection of 10,000 pixelated cat artworks launched on Ordinals. They are permanently inscribed on the Bitcoin blockchain and immutable. Each Bitcoin Cats NFT is more than just a PFP. It serves as a key component within the whole ecosystem and offers unique functionalities and benefits.

There have been 3 stages in the crypto industry thus far.

Stage 1: Bitcoin/Blockchain is created-Competition are just forks of bitcoin.

Stage 2: Ethereum/Blockchain/Smart Contracts- A new innovative way to create an ecosystem built on  Ethereum’s network via SC’s.

(Everything we know about crypto is just adaptations or layer 2s trying to make the blockchain of stage 1 and stage 2 better and more efficient.)

Stage 3: Kaspa/BlockDag- The realization that the true solution cannot be achieved on Blockchain. With BlockDAG, scaling of PoW is now possible without sacrificing security, decentralization or speed. 

This stage has only just begun. Many of the brightest minds and influential people in the crypto space are unaware of stage 3. They are distracted by ETFs and institutional players who move much slower than the pace of this industry. Stage 3 will likely last many years and if you hold $Kas right now, you are at it’s infancy. Your life will be changed.

Ethereum is a 2021 bubble that already popped. Doesn’t mean it’s worthless or won’t be used anymore. But the growth story has ended. And growth stories drive market prices. It’s literally being vampire attacked by a dozen newer, faster and cheaper chains with superior technology.

Why Ethereum Maxis should love Solana

A longpost rant by Mr F, proposer of the first block of ETH2 and solidity developer since 2018

- Philosophy of Decentralization
Whether or not you like Solana personally, it is the first majorly successful smart contract network that isn't a clone of the Ethereum Virtual Machine. (EVM)
This is fantastic for the general ideology of cryptocurrency and decentralization.

Other L1s like Polygon, Binance Smart Chain, and even TRON are based on the EVM, as are all Ethereum Layer 2s. (that I know of)
If there is a fatal flaw in the EVM, Solana is unaffected.

Competition means pressure on the Ethereum ecosystem and developers to do better or be left behind.
If you want Ethereum to improve, you should want Solana to be good competition.

- Cost
Solana is extremely cheap to use, and this is great for users.
It seems like a clear advantage at the surface level, but I think many don't understand 𝑤ℎ𝑦 Ethereum is so expensive.
Expensive = bad, Ethereum sucks. But this is not the truth.

Despite what you might read on CT, high costs are caused by an extreme level of DEMAND.
Ethereum is expensive 𝑏𝑒𝑐𝑎𝑢𝑠𝑒 it is good, otherwise nobody would use it and transactions would be cheap.
"Nobody drives in New York, there's too much traffic!"

Scaling is being worked on, but for now you are pretty much choosing between cost and security.

- Decentralization
I need to preface this that I'm not an expert on validators or network security.
Ethereum and Solana validators work differently, and one is not exactly comparable to the other.
Hardware requirements for Solana validators are extremely high, but as there's no SOL requirement it might still be more accessible to an average person than acquiring 32 ETH.
(not counting things like RPL and LIDO since this is about adding network security with individual validators)

With that said, there are only 1,951 Solana validators at the time of writing, versus 902,167 for Ethereum.
This difference in level of centralization and security should be shocking to someone who assumed they are more or less the same.

You might say hey, most of those Ethereum validators are probably owned by a few large groups.
Maybe this is true... but can't the same be said about Solana with its much lower figure?
While we can't know for sure, I feel confident saying there are probably many more individuals like myself who only have one Ethereum validator, just running it for the good of the network, than there are Solana validators in total.

Yes, Ethereum has problems and could be more decentralized, but it's still not even in the same ballpark - Ethereum is far more secure.

- So is this just bait?
No, despite the current difference in level of centralization, Solana can improve.
Optimizations, hardware advancements, or even just greater adoption (more validators) could all help Solana become less centralized and more secure.
Despite being "more" secure on paper, Ethereum still has a chance of encountering fatal flaws that Solana doesn't have.

- Solana Development Issues
I'm working on a game for Solana, and while I'm not greatest developer, I think most will find the learning experience challenging.
It's completely foreign for an Ethereum veteran, all basic functionalities are completely different and Rust is a more difficult language to understand.
Documentation quality is poor, frequently outdated or just non-existent, and libraries are lacking.
At the moment most creators are just using the default token programs for shitcoins and NFTs, there's a lack of experimentation and innovation.

On the other hand, Solana has a large and growing base of loyal users, which means there is money on the table and developers will crawl through the mud for it eventually.
And, Ethereum faced all of the same problems when it was newer and still growing.
If Solana is here to stay, these things will improve.

- Smart Contract Culture ("Programs" on Solana)
This one is probably the largest problem for me, and has two distinct issues.
First, solana programs are upgradeable by default. They can be made immutable, but nobody cares.
So? Anything can be rugged by a rogue developer.

Second, program verification (like smart contract verification on Etherscan) is disregarded.
If the program can be upgraded at any point, it doesn't really matter, but both immutability and program verification are needed for security.
Verified source also helps new developers learn difficult techniques and build from them instead of reinventing the wheel.

On the other side of this, I hope that with the recent acquisition of Solscan by Etherscan will lead to growth in both of these areas.
Otherwise, I fear the change will only occur after it becomes enough of a problem.
It's a bit like "Safety regulations are written in blood".

[ note: I started drafting this a few days ago, and since then Mango Farm rugged... ]

- Conclusion
Ethereum is far more secure than Solana, and safer for large amounts of money or long term NFTs.
However, it is now too expensive for most users and developers due to high demand.

Layer 2s are accessible, but very fragmented.
Other EVM L1s like Polygon and BSC feel like L2s, copies of Ethereum, but they don't share the security of Ethereum.
L2s like Optimism and Arbitrum supposedly do, but tend to have other risks like centralized sequencers.
They aren't diverse enough from Ethereum to offer anything new, and I don't feel confident many of them will still exist in 10 years.

Solana offers more value to cryptocurrency than most of those because it isn't based on the EVM, and it's cheap and fast.
But it's very centralized compared to Ethereum, and there are severe issues with the culture of upgradeable programs (contracts) and source code verification.
Only a strong push from the entire Solana community can change this culture.

Ethereum developers and users should use their years of experience to help with these problems, for the benefit of both networks.

I plan to contribute with:
- "Eth Developers guide to Solana" thread
- Advanced game project with verified source + immutable deployment
- Something else spicy

Something big is brewing in the Solana ecosystem: Crypto Undeads. This 10,000-strong collection isn't just another drop; it's a convergence of narratives, communities, and a bold mission👇

Solana 🤝 Ethereum

Their aim to bridge Solana and Ethereum is monumental. With communities converging across chains, this project stands as a unifying force in the space.

Unique Art

They've adopted a cool pixel art style that blends punk vibes with awesome digital portraits, making them stand out with clean aesthetics. It's a nod to inclusivity.

Defying the Narrative

In the face of "NFTs are dead" headlines, Crypto Undeads emerges as a rebuttal, branding themselves "crypto undeads" – kind of catchy, right? 
It's a testament to blockchain resilience, a narrative that resonates across the entire space.

Clear Vision

@knownasdollar , one of the most respected and well-connected individuals in the Punks community, set out with a vision—to forge one of Solana's most robust IPs. He wants the project to be the long-term hold for collectors on Solana, just like punks are on Ethereum.

Big Hype & Cool Collabs

The collaborations are staggering. Partnerships with @CyberKongz, @KaijuKingz, @Claynosaurz, @PirateNation, @assetdash, and @ChimpersNFT signal an embrace of diverse communities, stirring up unparalleled excitement.

Fair & Open for Everyone

They're meticulously handpicking allocations to prevent bots from taking over, ensuring equal shares for Solana and Ethereum communities and making sure everyone gets a fair chance.

Finally, with the market looking good and Bitcoin receiving a thumbs-up soon, the timing couldn't be better.

I believe "Golden Ratio" is going to be the staple for gen art on Ordinals, as much as "Squiggles" and "Autoglyphs" were for Ethereum

On the surface, it's beautiful art, but on a deeper level it represents an important transition that is about to happen in Ordinals.

Why do I think that? It's both a recursive and cursed collection.

Recursive inscriptions were an incredibly innovative feature added to the Ordinals protocol, allowing you to reference data from other ordinals last year.

I expect recursiveness to grow in popularity, as it is a much cheaper inscription option and enables a new level of composability between ordinals that wasn't previously possible. I predict we will see an explosion in recursive PFP collections, as much as we will see an explosion in recursive gen art collection.

Why do I think this particular collection warrants to be the "grail" of recursive collections? Just look at it. The art itself is recursive, and what better to express this recursiveness by using the most popular proportion in nature - the golden ratio.

Bitcoin Cats is the GameFi platform for the Bitcoin Ecosystem. Through mapping the Bitcoin Assets (BRC20, Ordinals NFT and others) to Ethereum (and other Layer2) networks, BitcoinCats brings many new elements to the Bitcoin Assets, including but not limited to Play2Earn, Staking, Farmland, SocialFi and many others. The mission of BitcoinCats is to build the next-gen gaming ecosystem across Bitcoin and EVM networks, with the communities of both sides, together!

Genesis #BitcoinCats #NFTs will soon launch on @bakery_swap!

Bullish Points
✅ Token
✅ Game
✅ NFT

Token
$1cat is the native token of Bitcoin Cats Gaming Ecosystem. It is originally inscribed on Bitcoin and part of it is bridged / wrapped to Ethereum to benefit from the well developed DeFi and GameFi infrastructure.

$1CAT is the Utility token with the BitcoinCats gaming ecosystem, which can be used to buy & upgrade in-game assets including the avatars, pets, equipments, farmlands and so forth. It also serves like tickets, enabling players to access special features. Finally, it is also a memecoin, with a super cute cat as its logo.

Game
Bitcoin Cats is a versatile gaming platform that offers more than just pixel games; it features AAA-level 3D MMORPGs, bringing a new dimension to gaming. The platform encompasses a range of Web3 functionalities including mining, NFT trading, and DAOs, as well as traditional Web2 elements like PvP, PvE, and guild formation. The gameplay is dynamic, with continuous updates to keep the experience fresh and engaging.

NFT
BitcoinCats NFT is the collection of 10,000 pixelated cat artworks launched on Ordinals. They are permanently inscribed on the Bitcoin blockchain and immutable. Each Bitcoin Cats NFT is more than just a PFP. It serves as a key component within the whole ecosystem and offers unique functionalities and benefits.

Ethereum is a 2021 bubble that already popped. Doesn’t mean it’s worthless or won’t be used anymore. But the growth story has ended. And growth stories drive market prices. It’s literally being vampire attacked by a dozen newer, faster and cheaper chains with superior technology.

Why Ethereum Maxis should love Solana

A longpost rant by Mr F, proposer of the first block of ETH2 and solidity developer since 2018

- Philosophy of Decentralization
Whether or not you like Solana personally, it is the first majorly successful smart contract network that isn't a clone of the Ethereum Virtual Machine. (EVM)
This is fantastic for the general ideology of cryptocurrency and decentralization.

Other L1s like Polygon, Binance Smart Chain, and even TRON are based on the EVM, as are all Ethereum Layer 2s. (that I know of)
If there is a fatal flaw in the EVM, Solana is unaffected.

Competition means pressure on the Ethereum ecosystem and developers to do better or be left behind.
If you want Ethereum to improve, you should want Solana to be good competition.

- Cost
Solana is extremely cheap to use, and this is great for users.
It seems like a clear advantage at the surface level, but I think many don't understand 𝑤ℎ𝑦 Ethereum is so expensive.
Expensive = bad, Ethereum sucks. But this is not the truth.

Despite what you might read on CT, high costs are caused by an extreme level of DEMAND.
Ethereum is expensive 𝑏𝑒𝑐𝑎𝑢𝑠𝑒 it is good, otherwise nobody would use it and transactions would be cheap.
"Nobody drives in New York, there's too much traffic!"

Scaling is being worked on, but for now you are pretty much choosing between cost and security.

- Decentralization
I need to preface this that I'm not an expert on validators or network security.
Ethereum and Solana validators work differently, and one is not exactly comparable to the other.
Hardware requirements for Solana validators are extremely high, but as there's no SOL requirement it might still be more accessible to an average person than acquiring 32 ETH.
(not counting things like RPL and LIDO since this is about adding network security with individual validators)

With that said, there are only 1,951 Solana validators at the time of writing, versus 902,167 for Ethereum.
This difference in level of centralization and security should be shocking to someone who assumed they are more or less the same.

You might say hey, most of those Ethereum validators are probably owned by a few large groups.
Maybe this is true... but can't the same be said about Solana with its much lower figure?
While we can't know for sure, I feel confident saying there are probably many more individuals like myself who only have one Ethereum validator, just running it for the good of the network, than there are Solana validators in total.

Yes, Ethereum has problems and could be more decentralized, but it's still not even in the same ballpark - Ethereum is far more secure.

- So is this just bait?
No, despite the current difference in level of centralization, Solana can improve.
Optimizations, hardware advancements, or even just greater adoption (more validators) could all help Solana become less centralized and more secure.
Despite being "more" secure on paper, Ethereum still has a chance of encountering fatal flaws that Solana doesn't have.

- Solana Development Issues
I'm working on a game for Solana, and while I'm not greatest developer, I think most will find the learning experience challenging.
It's completely foreign for an Ethereum veteran, all basic functionalities are completely different and Rust is a more difficult language to understand.
Documentation quality is poor, frequently outdated or just non-existent, and libraries are lacking.
At the moment most creators are just using the default token programs for shitcoins and NFTs, there's a lack of experimentation and innovation.

On the other hand, Solana has a large and growing base of loyal users, which means there is money on the table and developers will crawl through the mud for it eventually.
And, Ethereum faced all of the same problems when it was newer and still growing.
If Solana is here to stay, these things will improve.

- Smart Contract Culture ("Programs" on Solana)
This one is probably the largest problem for me, and has two distinct issues.
First, solana programs are upgradeable by default. They can be made immutable, but nobody cares.
So? Anything can be rugged by a rogue developer.

Second, program verification (like smart contract verification on Etherscan) is disregarded.
If the program can be upgraded at any point, it doesn't really matter, but both immutability and program verification are needed for security.
Verified source also helps new developers learn difficult techniques and build from them instead of reinventing the wheel.

On the other side of this, I hope that with the recent acquisition of Solscan by Etherscan will lead to growth in both of these areas.
Otherwise, I fear the change will only occur after it becomes enough of a problem.
It's a bit like "Safety regulations are written in blood".

[ note: I started drafting this a few days ago, and since then Mango Farm rugged... ]

- Conclusion
Ethereum is far more secure than Solana, and safer for large amounts of money or long term NFTs.
However, it is now too expensive for most users and developers due to high demand.

Layer 2s are accessible, but very fragmented.
Other EVM L1s like Polygon and BSC feel like L2s, copies of Ethereum, but they don't share the security of Ethereum.
L2s like Optimism and Arbitrum supposedly do, but tend to have other risks like centralized sequencers.
They aren't diverse enough from Ethereum to offer anything new, and I don't feel confident many of them will still exist in 10 years.

Solana offers more value to cryptocurrency than most of those because it isn't based on the EVM, and it's cheap and fast.
But it's very centralized compared to Ethereum, and there are severe issues with the culture of upgradeable programs (contracts) and source code verification.
Only a strong push from the entire Solana community can change this culture.

Ethereum developers and users should use their years of experience to help with these problems, for the benefit of both networks.

I plan to contribute with:
- "Eth Developers guide to Solana" thread
- Advanced game project with verified source + immutable deployment
- Something else spicy

I realised that the 1559 burn is my absolute favourite mechanism in the #Ethereum EVM. It is the great equaliser.

Before 1559, miners had the privilege of tweaking gas limits and prices of transactions mined by themselves arbitrarily. Sure, they always carried an opportunity cost of doing so, but it was capability imbalance vs. normies. This made it extremely hard to gamify stuff.

With the 1559 burn, it doesn't matter if you're a normie or a miner, the burn will hit you exactly the same way: it goes up for everyone, it comes down for everyone, it burns into everyone.

This is amazing, because it's a mechanism that you can build gamification on top, that miners cannot evade.

For sure, miners will always have special opportunities. They can decide at the point of block production to transact or not vs. normies who have to publish their tx and cannot retract it. But the burn gives an anchor point for DApps to play with that is uniform across everyone.

Now, of course, the goal of the 1559 burn was meant to be a fee stability mechanism that DApps are unaware of... ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ ...for me it's one of the best mechanisms for my toy DApps to *be* aware of.

We’re blasting off today with a new deployment of Pyth Entropy and Price Feeds on @Blast_L2!

Blast is a new Ethereum Layer 2 blockchain and the first L2 offering native yield for ETH and stablecoins.

Developers on Blast can now integrate with over 400 real-time price feeds and a new innovative source of random numbers.

Learn more below:
ℹ️ About Blast

Blast is a new Ethereum Layer 2 blockchain and the first L2 offering native yield for ETH and stablecoins along with faster and cheaper transactions for users. Blast is backed by Paradigm, Standard Crypto, and eGirl Capital.

🔮 Random Numbers and Price Feeds—All #PoweredByPyth

A new L2 with native yield could unlock a new decentralized economy, driven by DeFi—perpetual trading, lending, and DEXs—as well as NFTs and SocialFi: these verticals would depend on a secure, reliable, and low-latency source of financial data and randomness.

This partnership recognizes Pyth Network as the preferred oracle partner of the Blast ecosystem. Pyth Entropy is designed to be the fastest source of decentralized randomness, and as such, is positioned to power the Blast Layer 2 economy and support its NFT ecosystem.

Pyth Entropy's integration into the Blast ecosystem will enhance its capabilities for supporting a multitude of Web3 verticals, such as NFT initiatives, prediction markets, and SocialFi. A random number solution can dictate outcomes for creative initiatives such as NFT creation and distribution, predictive markets and betting, and Web3 gaming.

Pyth Price Feeds are the lowest-latency and most available price feeds for smart contract developers, covering over 400 real-time data feeds across five major asset classes. Access to high-resolution and wide-ranging price data is paramount for building sophisticated DeFi primitives.

🗣 Quotes

“We’re proud to partner with Pyth Network, an oracle for financial market data, and now, on-chain random numbers,” said @PacmanBlur, core contributor at Blast. “Pyth Data will allow us to leverage the full potential of Blast’s native yield and rewards system, and enable users and developers to use and build cutting-edge Web3-native services on Blast.”

"We're excited to have Pyth Price Feeds and Pyth Entropy integrated on Blast's fast, secure, and innovative Layer 2 platform,” said Marc Tillement, Director at the Pyth Data Association. “With real-time market data and reliable random number generation, Blast users will benefit from enhanced DeFi experiences.”

I thought 1559 was stupid. But I went along since everyone else liked it, so I figured I must be the one missing something. They were right and I was wrong.

The reality here is that there are so many extremely smart people working on everything, that for every problem, the probability of finding a *good* solution is very high... Not just *a* solution that a small team came up with, but a *good* solution that a community came up with.

Of course, the governance overhead of weeding out a good solution of the many possible ones is high. But as long as we try to keep up I think it's a very nice place to be at.

TL;DR: The tech is just a means to an end. The real king maker here is the community effort.

Along these lines, the other realisation is why #Ethereum is king and will remain so for the foreseeable future.

I thought 1559 was stupid. But I went along since everyone else liked it, so I figured I must be the one missing something. They were right and I was wrong.

The reality here is that there are so many extremely smart people working on everything, that for every problem, the probability of finding a *good* solution is very high... Not just *a* solution that a small team came up with, but a *good* solution that a community came up with.

Of course, the governance overhead of weeding out a good solution of the many possible ones is high. But as long as we try to keep up I think it's a very nice place to be at.

TL;DR: The tech is just a means to an end. The real king maker here is the community effort.

🌟 Introducing the Revolutionary Sybil Defense Passport ETH Stamp

🚀 LAUNCH Alert! Introducing the new Passport ETH Stamp: Harnessing onchain transaction history with our advanced predictive model to verify the unique humanity of each Ethereum account.

🔗 ACTION NEEDED: Reverify your ETH Stamp now! Points for the older ETH Stamp have been removed. Reboost your Passport score easily - link your Ethereum address to earn points using the new Stamp.

🛠️ Drawing on our extensive experience in protecting the Gitcoin Grants program, we've continuously evolved our approach to Sybil defense. Today marks a significant milestone as we reveal our latest innovation, a direct product of in-depth Passport data analysis.

✨ Our revised Passport ETH Stamp is a game-changer and is the first in a series of attempts to reduce challenges in building a passing score! It uses onchain transaction history to differentiate real users from Sybils, elevating user verification to new heights.

🌟 New Scoring Opportunity! Users can now boost their Passport Score with 3 new onchain activity credentials:

🛡️ Eth Advocate: Earn +3.54 points
🌐 Eth Pioneer: Add +3.54 points
💎 Eth Maxi: Add +3.54 points

📈 This approach is a substantial improvement over previous methods that focused only on ETH balance, transaction count, and gas expenditures. By analyzing a broader range of onchain activities, our predictive model can more accurately assess the likelihood of an account being a unique real user, greatly enhancing security against potential exploits.

🔍 We acknowledge that the new Passport ETH Stamp might initially lower some users' scores. This is a step toward a more secure and accurate verification process using detailed onchain transaction data. We value your feedback and are committed to improving our solutions to better serve our community.

👥 For our users, the new stamp is a streamlined and organic way to boost your score. Simply link your Ethereum address and actively participate in the web3 ecosystem - it's that easy. This model is the first in our lineup aimed at simplifying human verification, and we're already working on more innovative solutions.

💡 The data-rich Ethereum blockchain serves as a foundational tool for non-intrusive, data-driven identity verification. Currently tailored for Ethereum Layer 1 activities, we're looking ahead to include Layer 2 in the future, expanding our scope and utility.

⚡ IMPORTANT: Refresh your ETH stamp in Passport today to review your new score. Be part of our journey to create a safer, more trusted onchain experience.

Yes, you really can lose all your ETH if you stake with Geth

This article is not an attack on Geth. I have the utmost respect for their team. Unfortunately, through no fault of the @go_ethereum team because of how widely used Geth is we need to have honest conversations about the risks of running Geth when it holds a supermajority of stake.

This week the @ethereum network witnessed another one of its execution clients, @NethermindEth, experience a bug that took all validators running Nethermind (~10% of the network) offline. This was a minor event because Nethermind is run by a minority of stakers.

The above is a graph of the total balance of one of my own validators that runs Nethermind. You can see that around 4am local time, the validator went offline when the bug first took place. The team released a patch ~4 hours later and by the time I installed it, the validator was back up and running around 9am local time. During this time, my validator was penalised at the same rate as what it earned rewards at. By 1pm on the same day, the validator balance was higher than it was before the outage. Overall a very minor inconvenience.

Many incorrectly assume that when running Geth, if a similar bug were to occur, the penalty would be similar. This is not true. This has nothing to do with Geth or the way Geth has been built but everything to do with how many people are running Geth.

According to https://t.co/iZ68ftk7wL ~84% of all validators on Ethereum are running Geth. Now in these staker’s defence, Geth is unarguably the best and most stable client. Whilst minority clients, like Nethermind this week, have been plagued with bugs and downtime, Geth has run faultlessly since the Merge (and long before). In my own experience, I have found higher resource requirements and more missed attestations on my validators when switching from Geth to a minority client.

Nobody wants to move away from Geth if they know they are more likely to experience more missed attestations and more downtime, especially those whose business model depends on uptime to advertise the highest yield, such as professional staking operators.

As of September last year, it is estimated that @LidoFinance, the largest stake operator, runs ~76% of their validators on Geth.

But I’m glad I’m running a minority client, even if I’m losing a few extra rewards here and there, not because I’m altruistic and am sacrificing a personal gain for the good of the decentralisation of the network, but because I know that my precious ETH is safe from a supermajority bug.

Are Ethereum Spot ETFs Inevitable?

SEC Commissioner Hester Peirce believes that spot Ethereum ETFs can gain SEC approval without resorting to lawsuits, drawing from lessons learned from the Grayscale court ruling that led to spot Bitcoin ETF approvals. While acknowledging the uniqueness of each ETF application, Peirce hints that the SEC's approach will be careful and informed by previous experiences.

“We shouldn’t need a court to tell us that our approach is ‘arbitrary and capricious’ in order for us to get it right,” said Peirce.

Several firms, including major names like BlackRock, Fidelity, and Grayscale, are in the race for SEC approval, with decision deadlines set from May to August. Opinions on the likelihood of approval vary, with some analysts like Eric Balchunas being optimistic, while others, like Mark Yusko, show skepticism, citing the SEC's general caution towards the crypto industry. SEC Chair Gary Gensler's remarks further temper expectations, emphasizing a meticulous approach to each crypto asset under federal securities laws.

#Ethereum & #PulseChain tips. If you're running a node, Geth is 4k i/o bound, so get a transcend t700 or samsung 990 pro, depending on if you have pci-e or pcie-4. If Erigon then single core bound. Thus 14900k is boss. 7950x3d will use the non 3d cores for higher boost, thus 14900k>7950x>7950x3d>anything else. More CPU cores, such as threadripper or other high core count cpus will lose as they have lower boost speed.

My guess, 14900k will beat 7950x3d by 10-14%. These things only apply to syncing. Once you're sync'd it's a whole new ball game. Syncing a geth archive node takes weeks. Erigon is faster, but still takes forever.

DDR5 doesn't like 4 sticks at all, it likes 2 sticks. Erigon and GETH seem to use like 70 and 90 GB of ram, so probably 64gig at double the speed might run faster than 128gb at half the speed. *yeah DDR5 sucks like that. DDR5 might not suck the same on servers or threadrippers with 2x or 4x the memory channels.

Overclocking hardware running software that might be used for finance ain't smart. ECC ram is good if you can run it.

Finally, if your cpu is truly pitiful you might be cpu bound instead of 4k i/o bound on Geth.

Finally. Proof of stake finality likely invalidates much of the security theater of building a whole chain from genesis, as you could just consider the last 15 minutes finality genesis. Then you can validate with just the last final checkpoint that's 15 minutes old instead of downloading and running 10 years of transactions. :)

The dominant client in the Cardano network comes from the IOG team.

If #Cardano is to be more resilient to bugs in the source code, there must be more clients that will be built by independent teams.

In all major networks, including #Bitcoin and #Ethereum, the version of the client that comes from the oldest (original) team is dominant.

It makes sense since this team designed the protocol and set up things like monetary policy, reward mechanism, etc. 

This client is the most time-tested.

Volunteers install the client on their nodes. The network is gradually becoming more distributed and decentralized.

Nodes producing new blocks are more important than user nodes that do not produce blocks.

It is not only the number of nodes in the network that is important but also the decentralization. 

Decentralization is a decisive factor regarding nodes that are important for the network.

There may be thousands of nodes in the network, but the ones that produce the blocks are critical to the functioning of the network. 

For example, with Bitcoin, it is only 10 nodes (pools).

If the operation of the network is dependent on a single client implementation, the risk of failure is relatively high.

See Figure 1.

A distributed network can be resilient to the failure of a node (or multiple nodes). 

However, the network is not immune to a bug in the source code. A bug can cause all nodes to crash at the same time.

The network can somehow deal with the node crash itself. But it may happen that the crash will require fixing the bug and restarting the network.

A preventive measure against network failure is client diversity. 

There must be more clients that will be implemented by other independent teams.

Different clients must be compatible with each other. 

This means that they will work exactly the same in terms of communication protocol and network rules.

The original team (in Cardano's case it's IOG) must make the formal specification of the protocol available.

See Figure 2.

Formal specifications are crucial because they provide an unambiguous description of how a protocol should function.

This includes details about the protocol's behavior, its expected inputs and outputs, and the sequence of operations it should perform.

It provides a reference point that can guide the development process and help ensure that the client is implemented correctly.

Not only the existence of alternative client implementations is important, but also their adoption by operators.

Ideally, the representation of individual clients in the network would be as proportional as possible. 

So if there are 4 client implementations, each client would have 25% representation in the network.

See Figure 3.

If there was a fatal failure of one client implementation, only 25% of the nodes in the network would be affected.

The remaining nodes with a different version of the client, i.e. 75% of the nodes in the network, would continue to work.

See Figure 4.

The diversity of clients, perhaps a little surprisingly for some, increases the decentralization of the network.

Having multiple teams ensures that no single team has undue influence over the network’s development or direction. 

This aligns with the principle of decentralization, which aims to prevent any single entity from having too much control.

In the Cardano ecosystem, several teams plan to build an alternative Cardano client.

The team building the TypeScript implementation is probably the furthest along. 

Their version is still far from becoming a full-fledged client, but it handles basic operations such as fetching blocks and syncing the chain.

Building an alternative client is complex and expensive. 

Additionally, IOG regularly deploys upgrades. This adds new functionality.

All existing clients will need to keep up with the client from the IOG team in the future. 

In practice, this means implementing all upgrades.

Having more clients on the network also means being more vigilant about network upgrades. 

Network upgrades are currently handled by the hard-fork combinator.

A wider diversity of clients can complicate this process.

Teams building alternative Cardano clients should be an integral part of the ecosystem, including funding for which $ADA coins from the project treasury should very likely be used.

This is a challenge for the community. 

Decentralization is the responsibility of the community, so it should ensure that Cardano is decentralized at the client level.

If blockchain networks are to become the financial backbone of the world, it is necessary to ensure their 100% reliability. 

This is currently not guaranteed.

The Cardano community should think about what steps lead to a higher diversity of clients.

Read the article about the topic with more details: https://t.co/ah8gC8yDTq

We are open sourcing the Ethereum solo stakers mappings we’ve been curating internally. 

Especially recently, we’ve seen a wave of interest in incentivizing solo stakers—some of the most competent and mission driven operators in the industry, to participate in new networks and extensions of core Ethereum staking. 

But the problem is that these folks are not easy to identify onchain. The list we have curated solves for this. 

Based on state of the art ML work and a lot of hardening over the past 7mos by putting it through the ringer with different partners, we are very confident in the degree of signal it carries—especially in filtering out whitelabeled solos.

We think this can be a powerful tool in adding sybil resistance to curated sets, as well as in airdrops that might want to target solo stakers.

Today we are releasing the first version of the list, which covers indices 1 to 500,000.  Over time we will be releasing refreshes bringing it closer to the present.

#Celsius Network wallet transfers $36 million in Ethereum to #Coinbase and #FalconX Amid Bankruptcy Proceedings. What is going on?

• The transactions signal ongoing activity from the defunct DeFi lending platform as it addresses bankruptcy settlements.
• Over $621 million in Ether has been moved to various exchanges since November 2023 as part of Celsius's payout strategy to creditors.
• Celsius aims to unstack Ether holdings to facilitate asset distributions and manage restructuring costs.
• The company's mining subsidiary, NewCo, set up to assist with bankruptcy, reports increased Bitcoin holdings and yield gains, despite a cash balance reduction.

We can compare the relative scale of #Ethereum derivative markets to #Bitcoin, considering the dominance of futures open interest. 

BTC perpetual swaps accounted for 55% of open interest in Jan-2022, which has since risen to 66.2%.

At Messier, we’re all about creating the best possible user experiences and continuously driving innovation to shape our next-gen #DAO on the #Ethereum blockchain.

Discover our latest enhancements:
☑️ Batch Reward Claim: We've made it easier for you to claim your MTT and MOTT pool rewards with our new batch reward claim feature.
☑️ MEV Attack Resolution: Swap operations are now safer than ever; we've tackled MEV attack vulnerabilities to secure low-liquidity token transactions.
☑️ UI/UX Enhancements: We've ironed out minor UI and styling quirks across various screen sizes for a smoother experience.
☑️ Off-Chain Server Expansion: To boost our system's performance and security, we've scaled up our off-chain server queues.
☑️ Voting Integrity: Halos obtained before the activation of a proposal are eligible to vote, enhancing the fairness and integrity of our voting process.
☑️ Dynamic Voting with Unstaking: Unstaking a Halo will now result in the automatic revocation of the member's vote, ensuring that votes accurately reflect current community sentiment.
☑️ Token Icon Improvements: We've upgraded how token icons are displayed and improved the proposal appearance.
☑️ Post-Transaction Transparency: Tracking user actions after transactions has been enhanced, offering more transparency.
☑️ Pōwehi Waiting Period Standardization: The waiting period is now a consistent 87 hours, streamlining the process.
☑️ Fair NFT Listing Prices: To uphold fair market values, NFT listing prices must now be at least equal to the last sold price.

Inflation of #Bitcoin vs #Ethereum. 

When you factor in the burning of transaction fees, such as occurs with Ethereum (EIP-1559) since the Merge, it is *Bitcoin* that has the (significantly) more challenging task of requiring buy pressure to offset its inflation than ETH.

An order of magnitude in difference.

Ethereum has actually been net *deflationary* since the Merge, 502 days ago.

DAS is a way for an off chain light client to verify that nobody is trying to fuck with the data that goes into a new block on a rollup. This has been traditionally associated with DA and settlement layers like Ethereum and Celestia, but it's possible to cut out the middleman.

Several folks seem to be confused about security guarantees of validiums and sovereign rollups.

Rollups (smart contract rollups) provide full Ethereum security.

Validiums and sovereign rollups do not.

Ethereum foundation docs only treat rollups as legitimate L2s. https://t.co/Qb5U1cdUwf

My "explain like I'm five" description of @eigenlayer: 

EigenLayer is essentially a marketplace where protocols can "buy" security from Ethereum validators.

It's like TaskRabbit for Ethereum security - protocols request a certain amount of pooled security for a price and Ethereum validators choose which protocols to validate for.

Right now, Ethereum validation only extends to apps built on the EVM. With EigenLayer, Ethereum security can be extended outside of smart contracts.

I see a lot of confusion going around about Farcaster, what is it, what is Warpcast, etc. Here's a quick post explaining:

In their own words: Farcaster is a sufficiently decentralized social network built on Ethereum.

Users can create profiles, post short messages or "casts", follow others and organize into communities. It is a public social network similar in design to Twitter and Reddit.

Since Farcaster is public and decentralized, anyone can build an app to read and write data. Users own their accounts and relationships with other users and are free to move between different apps.

Farcaster is the underlying network, on top of which anyone can (and many people have) build apps with which to interact with the protocol

Warpcast is the most popular app. It's basically a Twitter/X clone, with a few tweaks [improvements imo].

You can set up an account by going to warpcast[dot]com. There's a small yearly fee required in order to prevent against bots, but that's currently being waved in about 15-20 countries.

Another way to engage with Farcaster is via Flink (flink[dot]fyi). This is a reddit-style interface (I really recommend trying it, it's amazing).

The same content, same accounts, just engaged with in an entirely new format. That's the beauty of Farcaster.

Warpcast actually went "down" yesterday. The app was overwhelmed, and people couldn't log in. But FARCASTER did not go down.

The underlying protocol worked just find, and other apps (such as Flink, or Supercast) kept running - so people were able to continue to engage with their content and others just fine. The beauty of decentralization.

DeSo (Decentralized Social) has been spoken about a lot over the last few years, and got a tonne of attention last year with Friend Tech. 

I'm a huge believer in DeSo and think it is the future, in no small part because it is significantly better for the end user (not to mention for developers).

A big problem in the past with all previous DeSo attempts has been the hyper financialization and ponzification of it all.

Farcaster has no native token, there is no ponzi, it is just a good product, built by great developers, and used by great developers.

I really recommend people actually try it out. Spend an hour or two on it.

There's SO MUCH cool stuff happening there, and it's rapidly gaining momentum.

Is it a Twitter/X killer? Probably not. Is it a Reddit killer? Probably not. Is it a Facebook killer? Probably not. 

Does it need to be? Probably not.

I used to think in order for a new social network to survive/win, it needed to "dethrone" an incumbent. I no longer think that is true -- if it is slowly gaining users, over time, it can grow into it's own social network in it's own right.

I don't think any of the existing social networks are likely to disappear or become irrelevant any time soon. 

But I don't think they need to, in order for Farcaster to be a success.

And, personally, I think it is in the best interests of the world for Farcaster to succeed.

Give it a go.

So some observations the last few weeks on Bitcoin ordinals:

- Less people dump it for quick profits unlike memecoins (current attention)

- More than 2x more volume than Ethereum nfts

- Fundamentally, nfts on bitcoin ironically make more sense than ethereum as all eth nfts are jpegs stored on AWS. If it’s not stored onchain, do you really own the nft?

- An ordinal is stored in the witness data of a block and tied to a utxo so it is stored in every single bitcoin node. So no censorship.

- I can understand that some will be like “ok who cares about tech bro”. It indicates that ordinals make more sense as nfts and as we all meme’d bitcoin as a “gold store of value” , I don’t see how nfts don’t fit that narrative as well on that same “store of value” chain.

- Bitcoin maxis are rich and hate them (you long everything bitcoin maxis hate fyi)

- We will get a huge nft bubble again but nfts have a skem reputation among normies (see celebs shill crap in 2021). Ordinals is a new concept.

- BTC ecosystem will increase because of new upcoming infra: more airdrops will be done to OG collections.

We can fix Ethereum fragmentation!

https://t.co/L1ae8j6w1G

Ethereum is going through the "puberty phase" of the rollup-centric roadmap. The rapid L2 scalability growth spurt has led to awkward fragmentation of composability, with a significant breakdown of network effects. L2s today are silos delineated by their sequencers, at bridging distance from each other as well as the L1.

Thankfully this fragmented state of affairs is temporary—we can do better than slow and asynchronous bridges. With shared sequencing plus real-time settlement we can (re)establish universal synchronous composability and (re)activate Ethereum's network effects with maximum thrust. Shared sequencing combines strengths of the modular and the monolithic theses.

We know Ethereum L1 as a data availability layer. Few realise Ethereum L1 can also provide shared sequencing for rollups, with preconfirmations. There's a simple design with no hard fork required. Such an Ethereum shared sequencer would be maximally secure and credibly neutral, and would enjoy a half-trillion dollar TVL head start. Ethereum L1 as the canonical shared sequencer—isn't that a compelling and unifying Schelling point? :)

#Ethereum I'm here to protect you from scams again. Scammers want to trick you into sending to their scam addresses. Here's one you might not have seen yet.

1. Create a new address with the same starting and ending characters as a real address that you've sent to.
2. Make a fake transaction so that etherscan shows as thought you actually sent to their fake address before. They copy the last send's value, and name of token (but it's a fake token, so usually grayed out with no logo showing in etherscan.)
3. Do this to lots of addresses and wait for people to fall for it.

Why does this trick work? Because people trust what etherscan showed them, instead of using their own history stored locally. Because they didn't use a test transaction and confirm with the other party, or yourself, whatever might see the real balance of the real token at the real address. Because showing just the starting and ending characters of an address is basically harmful if scammers can just create addresses of their own with the same start and end and only the middle characters are different.

This is where devs can do better, by showing the start, end and middle. Basically, the idea of "fingerprint." Being used to make more human identifiable one long string from a different long string has been around a long time. For example, when you click the lock certificate and inspect an SSL security certificate. A simple fix would be to show some middle characters for now as well.

Every L2 venture will learn that it's impossible because Bitcoin cannot change enough to support the things required for a vibrant L2 environment. Both Ethereum and Cardano continuously upgrade to enhance your options as a developer to deploy effective, efficient, reliable, and secure L2s. 

For example, we are adding BLS support to Plutus V3 alongside the Hydra and Mithril projects that provide rich business and technical requirements for Cardano to evolve. Ethereum has a vibrant ecosystem of L2s that are well-represented in the roadmap for Ethereum's core protocol. 

Bitcoin will not change or add any additional functionality. This means EVERYTHING is insanely hard to do with Bitcoin L2s and usually requires CENTRALIZED or FEDERATED infrastructure to operate. 

If it's CENTRALIZED or FEDERATED, then it's not Bitcoin. Pay attention to architecture and design choices when investing in these startups.

#Ethereum I'm here to protect you from scams again. Scammers want to trick you into sending to their scam addresses. Here's one you might not have seen yet.

1. Create a new address with the same starting and ending characters as a real address that you've sent to.
2. Make a fake transaction so that etherscan shows as thought you actually sent to their fake address before. They copy the last send's value, and name of token (but it's a fake token, so usually grayed out with no logo showing in etherscan.)
3. Do this to lots of addresses and wait for people to fall for it.

Why does this trick work? Because people trust what etherscan showed them, instead of using their own history stored locally. Because they didn't use a test transaction and confirm with the other party, or yourself, whatever might see the real balance of the real token at the real address. Because showing just the starting and ending characters of an address is basically harmful if scammers can just create addresses of their own with the same start and end and only the middle characters are different.

This is where devs can do better, by showing the start, end and middle. Basically, the idea of "fingerprint." Being used to make more human identifiable one long string from a different long string has been around a long time. For example, when you click the lock certificate and inspect an SSL security certificate. A simple fix would be to show some middle characters for now as well.

economic security flippening
⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛⬛ 700%

Ethereum
 • 29.9M ETH staked
 • $2,525 per ETH
→ $75B of economic security

Bitcoin
 • 600M TH of hashrate*
 • $17.5 per TH**
→ $10.5B of economic security

*Expressing hashrate in TH is a common abuse of notation—the correct unit is TH/s.

**Bitmain sold the S21 in bulk at $14 per TH/s. The energy efficiency of the air-cooled S21 is 17.5J per TH. With a setup cost of $200K per MW of air-cooled datacenter there's an additional datacenter setup cost of $3.5 per TH/s, for a total cost of $17.5 per TH/s.

$17.5 per TH/s should be a conservative upper bound. The S21 can be overclocked to reduce the dominant nominal rig cost of $14 per TH/s. Should Bitmain itself deploy the hashrate the sticker price can be discounted by Bitmain's profit margin. Manufacturing billions of dollars of S21s will lead to economies of scale and better pricing from suppliers like TSMC as well as assemblers. Manufacturing and installing state-of-the-art S21s is one of many strategies to deploy hashrate. For example, old hardware acquired at a significant discount can cover some of the hashrate, especially post-halving. Datacenter costs can be partially recouped by reselling capacity at discount pricing, e.g. at $100K per MW to AI farms. Rig costs can also be partially recouped by reselling PSUs and scrap metal.

It’s a basic integration every smart contract chain with real developer and user adoption must have, to argue otherwise is to blindly ignore the data.

Have you listened to the latest @IOHK_Charles interview with @cryptorecruitr? A @Cardano_CF led discussion with Circle dating back to 2021 has not materialized into anything meanwhile multiple foundations for other L1s a fraction the size of Cardano have launched native USDC support on mainnet.

For all the talk about “RealFi” and having a meaningful positive impact on economic activity in the real world this is honestly a sad and embarrassing current state for the Cardano ecosystem. This is not about decentralization or Intersect or Voltaire or other stablecoins on Cardano. This is about giving Cardano users the option to choose the stablecoin they prefer and empowering developers to build more competitive products by tapping into USDCs global liquidity layer as the most widely adopted and trusted stablecoin ever created.

If you have read up until this point it must mean you care about the future growth and adoption of Cardano the same way we do, for this we say thank you. Terraforms by @mathcastles springs out of, and across, no less than 5 of Ethereum's most compelling art scenes:

🔴 Auteur — Made by a small indie team without outside backing. 
⚫ Conceptual — The central concept, a networked sculpture, takes precedence over traditional aesthetic, technical, or material concerns.
🟢 Dynamic — Offers continuously evolving experiences via programmatic and interactive avenues.
🔵 Onchain — Indefinitely retrievable with open composability thanks to storing all its data on Ethereum.
🟡 Runtime art — Uses the blockchain as an “always on computer” to construct and reconstruct its art, i.e. the crossroads of dynamic + fully onchain.

According to Messari's State of Cardano Q4 2023, we are growing in all relevant stats.

When you take other reports from Messari and compare #Cardano with projects like #Ethereum, #Avalanche, #Algorand, and others, you realize that we have to work on adoption.

See the Table.

Avalanche, Ripple (XRP Ledger), Algorand, and Ethereum lead in the number of daily transactions.

#Bitcoin, Ethereum, and #Solana lead in the number of active daily addresses.

In TVL, Ethereum, Solana, and Avalanche lead.

It stands to reason that older ecosystems have a larger user base. 

Cardano is still a young platform. The DeFi ecosystem is in its infancy, but it is developing dramatically.

The next bull run will be the first in which Cardano will have a DeFi ecosystem. I expect the number of users to increase.

In terms of the number of users, all ecosystems are roughly similar - they have several tens of thousands of users. 

Only Ethereum has roughly a 10x lead. With Solana, it may (or may not) be fake data.

The number of transactions is very high for some projects, especially Avalanche and Algorand. In the context of the number of users, they are far too high.

It is possible that in some use cases, a small number of users send a large number of transactions to each other.

It doesn't make sense with Solana, as each user would have to make an average of about 200 transactions per day.

It is possible that Messari does not distinguish between successful and failed transactions.

Some ecosystems are ahead of Cardano, but not too far. 

Cardano needs new users and significant partnerships.

USD-backed stablecoin would also help a lot. 70% of transactions on blockchains concern stables.

Hi @VitalikButerin , your perspective on decentralization is invaluable. As we unveil Cloudverse, our solution to node centralization challenges, we invite you to join the conversation.

In response to recent revelations regarding the concentration of @ethereum nodes in centralized data centers, OpSec reaffirms its commitment to decentralization. The findings, as outlined in a recent article, underscore the importance of addressing vulnerabilities associated with centralized hosting.

At OpSec, we have long recognized the need for a decentralized solution to node hosting. Our platform, Cloudverse, has been developed with this imperative in mind. Cloudverse simplifies the process of setting up nodes for Ethereum and other cryptocurrencies, democratizing access to node infrastructure.

By offering a user-friendly interface and one-click node setup, Cloudverse empowers individuals and organizations to participate in network validation and maintenance. This not only enhances accessibility but also reduces reliance on centralized entities, strengthening the decentralized fabric of blockchain networks.

The launch of Cloudverse represents a proactive step towards mitigating the risks associated with centralized node hosting. By decentralizing node infrastructure, we aim to fortify the integrity and resilience of Ethereum and other blockchain ecosystems.

As we continue to advance the principles of decentralization, OpSec remains committed to collaboration and partnership within the blockchain community. We invite feedback and engagement from industry leaders and stakeholders as we collectively work towards a more decentralized future.
